topic.title: Recommended Order for SERDES Selection

body.p: The previous sections detailed the rules for selecting SERDES lanes for connecting to the subsystems and for retimer mode. Selection of SERDES is typically done to simplify routing of signal traces on the printed circuit board. The following order is recommended for selecting the SERDES to use.

li.p: Select the SERDES lanes required for retimer datapaths first. The rules for the retimer paths are the most restrictive since the are limited to a 1:1 connection between bank A and bank B SERDES. The PAM4 and NRZ rules apply.

Select the SERDES lanes for Ethernet clients next. Consider the cage population rules that will need to be published in end-user documentation to address Ethernet PHY address mapping requirements and avoid Ethernet client re-provisioning scenarios whenever possible.

Select SERDES lanes for Interlaken interfaces. Use SERDES from the same bank for each Interlaken interface. Ensure Interlaken SERDES lane pairs with FEC map to SERDES lane pairs with FEC on the mate device. Ensure 4 SERDES are allocated for applications that do not require Interlaken but intend to use the Interlaken integrated packet test set.
Select SERDES for FOIC, OTL, and OTLC interfaces. OTN MLDs are on 100G SHI boundaries and can most flexibly be assigned to SERDES on a mix of SERDES banks.
Consider the lane reordering capabilities for each Interface as noted in Multi-lane Distribution (MLD) Interface Lane Ordering Requirements.
Select P/N swap during board layout to simplify the board design by minimizing trace cross overs. The P/N swap for each SERDES port and each direction (TX and RX) can be independently configured.
